item.title: dDocent install successes & failures on Linux supercomputers
item.description: Jon Puritz and some other developers have hacked out a nice pipeline, named dDocent (pronounced “docent”), for genomic assembly, read mapping, and SNP calling using NGS data from the RAD-seq family of sequencing strategies. dDocent is nice because it pulls together several top-of-the-line existing tools, and because it provides reference-based and de novo assembly options. Instructions for installing dDocent are given at the pipeline’s Bioconda Download and Install page, and are claimed to be “So easy your grandfather could do this….

item.title: How To Setup A Linux Supercomputer for RAD-seq
item.description: Here, I’m sharing a Gist that I recently wrote, and just updated today, about setting up an account on a Linux supercomputer for analyzing RAD-seq data (e.g. from ddRAD-seq, 2bRAD methods).
